references.A92COL03NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1992. Reply to Grobman on variation in OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS. Herpetol. Rev. 23:15-16.
references.B82COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Kansas. Second edition. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist., Pub. Ed. Ser. 8. xiii + 356 pp.
references.A84GOL02NAUS: Goldsmith, S. K. 1984. Aspects of the natural history of the rough green snake, OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS (Colubridae). Southwest. Nat. 29:445-452.
references.A91OLD01NAUS: Oldham, J. C., and H. M. Smith. 1991. The generic status of the smooth green snake, OPHEODRYS VERNALIS. Bull. Maryland Herp. Soc. 27(4):201-215.
references.B75MOU01NAUS: Mount, R. H. 1975. The Reptiles and Amphibians of Alabama. Auburn University Agricultural Experiment Station, Auburn, Alabama. vii + 347 pp.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B96DEG01USGP: Degenhardt, W., Painter, C., and A. Price.  1996. Amphibians and reptiles of New Mexico. University of New Mexico Press, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 429 pages.
references.B72MIN01NAUS: Minton, S. A., Jr. 1972. Amphibians and reptiles of Indiana. Indiana Academy Science Monographs 3. v + 346 pp.
references.B84GRO01NAUS: Grobman, A. B. 1984. Scutellation variation in OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS. Bull. Florida State Mus., Biol. Sci. 29(3):153-170.
references.B90COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
references.B84TEN01NAUS: Tennant, A. 1984. The Snakes of Texas. Texas Monthly Press, Austin, Texas. 561 pp.
references.B99BAR01USGP: Bartlett, R. D., and P. P. Bartlett. 1999. A field guide to Texas reptiles & amphibians. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.
references.B00WAL01USGP: Walley, H. D., and M. V. Plummer. 2000. Opheodrys aestivus. Catalogue of American Amphibians and Reptiles 718:1-14.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.A93PLU01NAUS: Plummer, M. V. 1993. Thermal ecology of arboreal green snakes (OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS). J. Herpetol. 27:254-260.
references.A92GRO03NAUS: Grobman, A. 1992. On races, clines, and common names in OPHEODRYS. Herpetol. Rev. 23:14-15.
references.A85PLU01NAUS: Plummer, M. V. 1985. Demography of green snakes (OPHEODRYSAESTIVUS). Herpetologica 41:373-381.
references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B70FIT01NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1970. Reproductive cycles of lizards and snakes. Univ. Kansas Museum Natural History Miscellaneous Publication 52:1-247.
references.B91CON01NAUS: Conant, R. and J. T. Collins. 1991. A field guide to reptiles and amphibians:eastern and central North America. Third edition. Houghton Mifflin Co., Boston, Massachusetts. 450 pp.
references.A85PLU02NAUS: Plummer, M. V. 1985. Growth and maturity in green snakes (OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS). Herpetologica 41:28-33.
references.A89PLU01NAUS: Plummer, M. V. 1989. Observations on the nesting ecology of green snakes (OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS). Herpetol. Rev. 20:87-89.
references.A97PLU01NAUS: Plummer, M. V. 1997. Population ecology of green snakes (OPHEODRYS AESTIVUS) revisited. Herpetological Monographs 11:102-123.
references.B71BAR01NAUS: Barbour, R. W. 1971. Amphibians and reptiles of Kentucky. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 334 pp.

habitat_description:
The vast range of the rough green snake comprises south New Jersey to Florida Keys; west to southeastern Kansas and Texas, well south into Tampico, Mexico (Conant and Collins 1998). The range includes central Oklahoma, north of the southern portions of the southern Great Lakes states, south into northeastern Mexico (Nuevo Leon, Tamaulipas) (Walley and Plummer 2000).

In Texas, this species is found in wooded meadows, pastures, and suburban gardens. Encounters are common along ponds, streams, and swamps. The range of the rough green snake includes the easternmost area of the Trans-Pecos region and the barren southern plains. It uses canyons as corridors and favors tree species with prevalent horizontally oriented limbs over vertical limbs (Dixon and Werler 2000). Degenhardt et al. (1996) reported sightings of the rough green snake in the Cimarron River, Fort Bliss, and Old Fort Cobb, but disregard the species as part of the New Mexico herpetofauna.

Forested wetland, Riparian, Scrub-shrub wetland, Forest - Hardwood, Grassland/herbaceous, Old field, Shrubland/chaparral, Suburban/orchard, Woodland - Hardwood

SE	-dense vegetation (vines, shrubs, trees) near water; often at forest edges or in fairly open forests; also overgrown pasture, tallgrass prairie, thickets, barrier islands; open marsh and spoil banks in Louisiana; pine-oak, mesic hardwood hammocks, and occasionally mangrove swamps in Florida.
